content.description:
A fun warm-up route!



Left of Kingdom of the Blind

Bolts

Start up a left facing corner which is harder than might be expected right off the ground. Clip the chain draw at the roof and pull a mini-boulder to gain less featured rock. Wander back and forth across the bolt line on big holds through the steeper territory until the wall angle eases. Here, you will be greeted by thin holds, tricky movement, and pumpy climbing until you clip the chains!



Starts up the left facing corner in the middle of the sector, ~4 m left of the Clockwork Orange orange streak. 

10 bolts, 2 fixed draws, rap rings+biners

Approach climb on big holds to a tenuous no hands rest in a shallow dihedral at the fourth bolt. Follow the orange streak to the right through sustained, beautiful climbing. A decent rest lets you regain control for a mini-boulder up high. Victory climb on big-holds to the chains. 

Sure to be a mega-classic....along with every other line on the wall. 



Look for the biggest orange streak, pretty much where the approach trail meets the wall. Just left of the jet black water stained rock. 

13 bolts, drop in anchor

Maybe the best for the grade at the crag! Climb big holds to the first bolt where the action begins. Clip the chain draw and pull a shouldery move into the undercling to set yourself up to gain the roof. Stem and weave back and forth across the bolt line on holds that seem like they're just good enough to keep going, but never good enough to rest on.

A sequenced slab section guards a proper rest just before the bulge at the top. Pull the bulge and cruise a sport run-out on big holds. 



Goes up the orange stain between the two more prominent orange streaks. Alternatively, starts just left of the broken corner/arch. 

10 bolts, rings w biners

Cruise up an easy pillar until the big holds run out. A techy traverse leads to a couple of good side pulls and a thin, bouldery crux. Race the pump to the chains!



The first line right of the right-most orange streak. 

10 bolts, rap rings+biners

Start up a shallow dihedral to pull onto the face; from here, pinch and stem your way up until you reach the chain. After this, the climbing promptly shifts to beautifully thin face climbing, capped by a boulder problem involving okay hands and really bad feet. Victory climbing above. 



Starts from on top of the rock pile towards the right end of the wall, climbs the right-most, faint orange/yellow streak.

10 bolts, rap rings w biners

Shared start with "Clockwork Orange", but take the left line of bolts. Sustained, technical climbing on thin but good holds leads to an easy crux boulder (easy if you're fresh) ending in a mid-height rest. Victory climbing to the chains, except that every bolt to bolt sequence has a dropable move! 



The left branch of the biggest orange streak. 

14 bolts, rap rings/biners

Climb a vertical crack/weakness (not crack climbing) which gives way to incredibly sustained face/slab climbing. This climb keeps you on your feet the whole time with multiple mini-boulders and extremely sustained climbing until the last bolt!



Towards the left end of the sector locate the right facing corner/small cave. This line is ~7 m to the right, starting with ~4 m of climbing up a groove/crack feature. Watch out for the unfinished line of bolts (as of July 2021) between the corner/cave and this line. 

12 bolts, rap rings/biners

climbs.name: Livin' in Paradise
climbs.fa: Craig McGee and Lindsay Andersen, September 2020

content.description: From Crag's Topo posted to Bow Valley Climbing Community with Permission! Livin in Paradise, 5.12a, 120m (5 pitches) Stanley Headwall, Yoho National Park   11 – 14 draws (depending on use of optional gear) (17+ draws if combining pitch 1 and 2) Optional #.75,# 1, #2 and #3 (BD) for pitches 2 and 5 (4 cams max) Pitch #1, 5.9 20m, 6 bolts.  At the right side of the ledge start up the small left-facing flake/pillar, then follow bolts and prickly climb up and left to a sloping belay stance below the overhanging 2nd pitch. Generally, climb left of the bolts as they are placed on the right to facilitate less rope drag if you combine pitches 1 and 2. If combining pitches 1 and 2, it is advisable to back-clean the first draw and use long slings on the second and last bolt on the 1st pitch   Pitch #2, 5.11c, 35m, 11 bolts (plus a couple of optional cams #.75-#3)  An awesome pitch. Step out right from the belay and climb up through excellent rock and ever steepening terrain. Once past the overhanging terrain, the route follows a crack for 8m. One bolt protects the wide section of this crack, but some people may prefer to use a couple of cams (#.75 - #3) in this crack section. No single crux, but lots of sustained climbing. Belay at the first set of bolts. There is one chained draw to help facilitate getting back to the first belay if you decide to rappel from here.   After you have belayed the second person up, bump the belay up and across to the far left side of the ledge. Do not use the belay with the black chain below the ledge (this is for rappelling). Instead, use the bolts that are up on the ledge.   Pitch #3 5.5, 17m 4 bolts Tread lightly. The climbing isn't hard, but the rock isn't great either! Belay on the obvious ledge at 17m. Do not connect this pitch with pitch #4, the rope drag would be bad.   Pitch #4 5.10a, 25m, 7 bolts.  Climb steep and impeccable rock for the first 4 bolts, then make an exposed, but moderate traverse out right, then up to a belay below the crux pitch.   Pitch #5, 5.12a 28m, 9 bolts (plus optional gear .75-#3)  Climb through a few approach bolts and up to the base of the steep seam/crack (steeper than it looks!!). Powerful pulls on perfect holds surrounding the crack lead to a problematic jam in a flaring finger pod. After the crux, a body length of overhanging hands leads to easier, but exposed terrain. This pitch can be climbed just using the bolts; however, some people may prefer to use a few cams (.75 - #3) in between a couple of the bolts. The crux bolt has a fixed chain draw to enable the pitch to be easily climbed at 5.11 A0 and help facilitate getting back to the belay when rappelling. Descent  It would be possible to belay a short 4th class section and then walk off, but all pitches are set up to rappel too.  Rap #1 Do a 70m, (two ropes) rappel directly to the midway ledge (fulling overhanging) orDo a 28m rappel to the top of pitch #4 (you will need to clip a few draws, and use the chain draw to get back to the pitch #4 belay. It is a 28m rap, and it's super steep, so tie knots at the end of the rope and be careful! Rap #2 25m. Use the chain draw on the traverse to help get back to the top of pitch #3 Rap #3 17m. Rap down to the black chain that is below the midway ledge. Watch for loose rock when pulling your rope.  Rap #4 55m, use two ropes to rappel from the black chain (just below the midway ledge) to the route's start. If you are savvy and have a 70m rope, you could get back to the belay at the top of pitch #2 and then back-clip and use the chain draw to rap to the top of pitch one. This option is not easy.   Rap #5 20m. Scramble back up the approach ledge and make one last rap to the ground.    Approach Park at the Stanley Glacier trailhead in Yoho National Park. Take the popular hiking trail to the enormous boulder below the main waterfall (Nemesis). Head up left towards a large orange circular piece of overhanging rock at the left side of the main cliff (1-1.5hrs). Locate a small ledge system that cuts in from the left side of the cliff. It is recommended to belay across the initial part of the ledge system (single belay bolt and several bolts on the traverse) as a fall would be critical. There is a handline that starts after the exposed section which leads down to the start of the route.   Small rack and bolts, see description

Pass marginal rock down low (consider stick clipping the second bolt) to gain a vertical layback flake. Trend up and right transferring to an overhanging layback crack; maintain core tension and race the pump until the wall eases to vertical. Bucket slam to a high rest before pulling one final slab mini boulder!



Far right of Nemesis Wall, look for the obvious, overhanging/right trending crack. This climb starts just down/to the left, the bolt line crosses the crack. 

10 bolts, rap rings w biners (shared with "Out  for Blood")

Pull through a couple meters of questionable rock at the base, choose your holds carefully and consider stick clipping. After that, enjoy the immaculate rock and amazing features as you pull a really steep and sustained 5.10! 

The angle eases as mid-height and slabs out at the top. Shared anchors with "Murderous Intent". 



Look for a series of shallow, oblique weaknesses on the right end of Nemesis Sector. This line follows these weaknesses. 

7 bolts, rings w biners

Traverse hard right just below the first bolt on good holds. The fun begins immediately- high feet and a big move brings you to a slightly strenuous clipping stance for the second bolt; here you can go either left or right to get to the third bolt before heading up a series of obvious weaknesses/flakes. A tricky slab sections waits for you at the top!

Bolt 3 is very blowable, and the fall could be quite serious. Consider prehanging a double or triple length draw in advance. 



From where the path comes up, head left and approximately half way up the hill. Look for where a giant flake has broken off at mid-height on the wall leaving a white scar. This is the bolt line that climbs into this scar. 

11 bolts, rings w biners

Pure joy- buckets down low, techy crimp face/slab up top. Amazingly elegant climbing that flows from the deck to the chains! Trust the high first bolt, it's safe!



Towards the right end of the sector, look for a series of oblique slashes/grooves. This is the first line to the left of the slashes, look for the big undercling/side pull down/right of the first bolt. 

9 bolts, rap rings/biners
Techy climbing, amazing rock. Developed by Gery Unterasinger and others.
